CHIEF COMPLAINT

Upper respiratory infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrew Mitchell is a 59-year-old male with a past medical history, significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension who presents today with an upper respiratory infection

The patient reports that he was doing a bit of work out in the yard in the last week or so when he started to feel really tired, was short of breath, and felt shortness of breath. He states that he thought it was because he was exerting himself. He denies any seasonal allergies at this time of the year, however, he notes that he has been wearing masks as much at the end of the summer and he thinks it was due to exertion. The patient denies any other symptoms such as muscle aches, joint pain, fatigue, or fever. He notes that his blood pressure has been pretty good for the most part since this episode of his high blood pressure, but notes that it has been a crazy year and a half and he was a little concerned about that. He has been monitoring his blood pressures at home, but has not had a refill of the lisinopril. He is regular about monitoring his glucose levels while he is going to work during the week. He does not have any episodes of episodes of fevers, chills, or weight loss, but he does feel a little warm and has been taking ibuprofen, Tylenol for any fever. isEnabled

He denies seasonal allergies, but states that his recent cold has not been as bad as last time. He adds that he does not believe he has a viral syndrome, but his wife got him into barre classes, to help him relax and I think he is doing well with his weight loss and his weight control.


REVIEW OF SYSTEMS


 Constitutional: Denies fevers.
 Musculoskeletal: Endorses joint pain and joint pain in his lower extremities and he does have some pain to palpation of his elbows bilaterally on his lung exam. He reports that his hemoglobin A1c is a little elevated at 8, but I believe that is due to his exertion and not to his allergies. I have referred him to psychotherapy for the next few months to help strengthen his immune system and he will follow up with me in a few months if he continues to improve.

Ms. Hernandez states that her reflux has not been as bad as she had initially thought. She continues to take methotrexate 2.5 mg once weekly, but notes that when she gets stressed, she has noticed that she starts to get stressed and it flares up again, so she tries meditation, trying running, and trying dietary modifications. She reports that she does not have any episodes of nasal congestion. She also denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, or edema.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency room follow-up.


HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Albert Diaz is a 62-year-old male, with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and kidney transplant, who is here today for emergency room follow up. He was admitted to the emergency room after experiencing dizziness and feeling woozy over the weekend. He states that he was staying on top of his blood sugar readings, but he was not monitoring what he was eating at the time of the visit. He notes that when he got home from the visit, he felt a lot better and was able to go back to his regular routine. He denies any fevers, chills, or shortness of breath. He also notes that he has been taking immunotherapy meds, which have been pretty good so far. He has been diligent about following his diet, following doctors orders, and has been compliant with the meds. He reports that he does not end up in the hospital at this time, however, he does end up with a kidney transplant if he is not able to manage his immunosuppression medications. He adds that he is going back to Dr. Reyes for the kidney transplant.


The patient reports that his depression has been going on for a year-and-a-half, but it has not been as bad as he had thought. He is doing well with his meditation and is not as anxious as he was when he saw Dr. reyes. The last time he saw him was about 3 weeks ago, and everything seemed to be fine. He does not have any carotid bruits, however he does hear that slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, but we heard that in the past. He continues to eat well and has not had any episodes of dizziness or nausea over the past week. He endorses lightheadedness and dizziness on the weekend, but denies any other symptoms.
 Medical Reasoning: The patient has been very diligent with his meds and has continued to follow his diet. He attributes his depression to being very busy on the weekends, but has not seen any improvement in his sleep since that visit.

She denies any past medical history of any surgeries in the past. She utilizes Motrin 800 mg 3 times a day with food. She does occasionally flex her arm when she moves her arm, but mostly when I do that type of motion. She also takes Flonase, which does not appear to have any abnormalities at all. The patient states that she has had a trauma of a stabbing of the left arm, which she states she did not have a fracture. She notes that when I press on her arm she has pain when I stress especially her thumb, and flex her thumb. She endorses numbness when I move her arm.


The patient states she has a history of allergies and takes flonase.

She reports that she feels numbness with movement when I bend her arm and she states that the pain is localized to her distal radius. She is also concerned with the pain associated with hitting her arm with the backhand. She believes that this may be a strain and maybe a contusion to her muscle, from hitting the arm. She treats her pain with ice, ice, and anti inflammatory. She will treat her pain conservatively. She plans to discontinue motrin, 800 mg twice a day, with food if she does not get any better in the next week or so.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

New breast reduction consult.


The patient is a 25-year-old female with symptomatic macromastia, presenting for evaluation of breast reduction. She states she has been going to the chiropractor for a few years. She denies any numbness or tingling in the breasts, but she notes that she has always been in the back of her mind when she was in high school. She reports that she drinks a little wine on occasion, and for school, she is currently studying psychology. The patient denies any chest pain, neck pain, or migraines. She notes that her breasts have been in her mind for approximately 6 or 7 years, but has not had a mammogram or ultrasound of her breasts yet. She is currently employed as a chiropractor and has attempted nonsurgical treatments, but the patient states that she is an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty, which she states is a good time for the patient to be on her new plan. She does have bilateral breasts with severe ptosis bilaterally, but notes that it takes about a year for a scar to mature in line. She also notes that the breasts are not as large as she would like them to be due to the weight loss. She adds that she does not have a family history of breast cancer, however, she does have a mother who is a breast reduction specialist and works at the clinic. She attributes her pain to her breasts when she is working at her desk all day. He attributes her breasts to her back pain and neck pain. He denies any other symptoms such as back pain, nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain, but attributes her breast pain to the presence of the mammollectomy and mammogram. He also denies any past breast reduction surgeries, such as breast reduction, breast enlargement, or breast reduction in the past. He states that he has tried nonsurgical treatment, but it has not been beneficial for him. He notes that he is currently on his new plan, which he believes is not going to be blue cross, but may be changing. He does not plan to have any children in the future, but he is going to continue to utilize his chiropractor services for the next 6 to 7 weeks to help with his pain and discomfort. He is also going to start wearing a regular bra for about 6 weeks after surgery, which should help with the scarring and swelling of the breast tissue. He will also continue to use a nipple graft for approximately 1 to 3 weeks after the surgery to help prevent fluid from building up in the breast. He would like to see the breast reduction plan for his children as soon as he is able to get his insurance information. He has also been referred to the Breast reduction Specialist, who will assist with the surgical treatment plan for the reconstruction of his breast. The breast reduction will be performed in the clinic on 1st of July, which we will discuss with the patient on how to proceed with the surgery.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Patient reports history of psoriatic arthritis.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Judy Gomez is a pleasant 53-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for ongoing management of psoriasis. The patient reports that she took an extra prednisone dose on the week that she got her Covid shots. She states that she was doing well at that time, but notes that when she is moving around a lot, her feet tend to hurt a bit more. She notes that she has been on methotrexate 3 times per week, which seems to be enough to help with her joint pain. She denies any extra pain with the first dose, however, she notes that there were a couple days there that she felt absolutely horrible until she took it again a week later. She also notes that the pain is due to prednisoprexate, which can increase bruising when she bumps her feet. She reports that her feet have been feeling absolutely horrible for a long time now, but she does not know where the bruits are coming from, so she is working on discontinuing the medication. She has an appointment to get her blood drawn for the next time. She will contact the clinic if she experiences any pain with her next visit.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Hyperthyroidism.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana Scott is a 100-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a heart murmur. The patient states that she has had severe pains in her legs for approximately 6 months. She denies any chest pain, dizziness, or fatigue. She notes that she does not have any allergies to medicines that she tries to use, but notes that they are completely new as far as she is concerned. She states that her symptoms are consistent with severe aortic stenosis, which she states is due to bilateral leg pain over the last month, considered tavr evaluation following echocardiogram, and she denies any acute distress. She does take statin every day, however, she is on meclizine for this. She reports that some of her lightheadedness and dizziness is related to the aorta stenosis and we will consider a monitor to assess overa- overall cardiac structure and function, as well as her valve view of the carotids. She has not noticed any significant palpitations or lower extremity edema in the past 6 months, but she does feel short of breath at times, especially if she is walking too fast or too long. She is taking levothyroxine, which does not appear to be associated with a heart attack or stroke.


Ms. Scott reports that she is doing well at this time, but has not seen any improvement in her symptoms since that time. She also notes that her blood pressure has not been as high as it was 6 months ago, so she is not sure if this is related with her heart attack, but I do believe that it is mainly due to her leg pain, which is most likely due to severe Aortic Stenosis, for which she is currently asymptomatic and has no history of coronary artery disease or heart failure.

I advised him that if he has any other symptoms or worsenings give my office a call we will get him in or get him referred to the er if needed any questions about that. He was provided with a referral for gastroenterology and was referred to a specialist to review his current symptoms and treatment options. Additionally, I recommended that he continue his metformin 500 mg twice a day. I also recommended that we check his hemoglobin A1c in the morning to see if there is any changes in his weight. He will also be referred to an eye referral to ophthalmology to check his eyes for any retinopathy. If his symptoms do not improve in the next month, we will start him on metformIN 20 mg once a day and we will send him back in about a month. If he is not compliant with his regimen, we may need to change his medication.
INSTRUCTIONS

After reviewing the patients examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his recent symptoms. I have explained to him that his symptoms are consistent with constipation and that he should continue with Norvasc. He should contact me if he encounters any issues. I encouraged him to continue with the norvasc if he wishes to contact me but otherwise there is really nothing else to add for that did we forget anything or do you need refills for anything.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

An ankle injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 45-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of an ankle injury sustained while playing basketball today. The patient states that he landed awkwardly while going for a lap while he was playing basketball. He has a job where he can elevate his ankle regularly. He reports that he has been having trouble walking since he was in a good rhythm going to the gym. He states that when he gets back into working out, he will fall and hurt his ankle. He describes his ankle as feeling a bit bruised up and a bit swollen when he is on crutches. He notes that it feels like he is going to possibly injure his ankle more if he tries to ambulate on it. He adds that he is trying to get back into playing basketball, but it takes a lot of effort to get him back to a good place. He denies any specific injury. He continues to work from home, however, he does play basketball at the gym and enjoys participating in the basketball league. He also enjoys playing basketball with his buddies. He is very active in the gym, but has not been able to participate due to his physical limitations. He currently works from home so he does not participate in basketball tournaments. He attributes his ankle pain to the ambulation of his teammates. He does not like to push on his ankle, however. He feels it is unstable when he ambulates. He endorses ambulation and ambulation. He explains that he likes to keep up shots from way out past the 3 point line. He believes that it is not a good idea for him to do that at this time. He counseled the patient on the importance of strength training and that he should be able to stand on his right ankle for the next 3 to 6 months. He advised the patient to keep his ankle elevated regularly. I advised him to ice his ankle and ice it. I also advised him that if he moves his ankle too much, it will cause him to feel some of that instability when ambulating. He was advised to ice the ankle and keep it elevated. He will follow up with me in 3 months to assess his progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Pain in the right cheek bone.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 54-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right cheek pain. The onset of his pain began 2 or 3 months ago. He states that he has been experiencing stabbing pain in his right eye for approximately 2 months. He denies any weakness or tingling in his eyes. The pain usually resolves after a few minutes but sometimes it gets super hot. The patient has been taking Tylenol, ibuprofen, and Motrin that has not helped with the pain. He has tried rubbing some tiger balm on the pain, but it does not help. He also notes that the pain lasts for approximately 1 to 2 minutes but generally lasts for about an hour. He adds that he does not have any symptoms like this anywhere else on his face including the other side of his face. He notes that when he smiles or smiles his smile seems equal on both sides of his eyes, which seems to be unchanged. He endorses no weakness on the right side of the face

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss.
 Musculoskeletal: Reports right eye pain. Denies dyspnea on exertion or weakness in the left eye.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient presents today with a history of multiple sclerosis, brain tumors, and brain tumors. He reports that he occasionally gets headaches but denies any specific side effects of migraines.
 - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed treatment options today. I encouraged the patient to follow up with me in 1 month to discuss treatment options. I recommended that we start with the tegretol first. I advised the patient that if his pain does not resolve in that time, we may consider surgical intervention such as surgery to decompress the nerve. I also advised him that we may need to do some genetic testing just to make sure that it will be safe for him. He will also be referred to a neurosurgeon for further evaluation.

The CT was also reviewed today and revealed no evidence of a fractured spine.
